description: From Middle English progenie, from Old French progenie, from Latin prōgeniēs, from prōgignō (“beget”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Offspring or descendants considered as a group.
examples: I treasure this five-generation photograph of my great-great grandmother and her progeny.

entries.meaning: (countable, figurative) A result of a creative effort.
examples: His dissertation is his most important intellectual progeny to date.
